H.text: India and Pakistan agreed to start a bus service linking two cities on either side of their border crossing.
H.ref: India and Pakistan Wednesday agreed to start a bus service in October linking two cities on either side of their only border crossing as part of an ongoing peace process, an official here said.

H.text: India and Pakistan agreed on the bus service to link divided Kashmir.
H.ref: In April, India and Pakistan agreed on the first bus service to link divided Kashmir in almost 60 years as part of a peace process begun in January 2004.

H.text: A bus service runs between Srinagar and Muzaffarabad.
H.ref: The first bus service spanning divided Kashmir in nearly 60 years ran simultaneously Thursday from Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian Kashmir and Muzaffarabad, capital of the Pakistan-administered zone.

H.text: The peace process between India and Pakistan was launched in 2004.
H.ref: The peace process was launched in early 2004 to resolve eight issues including the dispute over the Muslim-majority Himalayan state of Kashmir, which is divided between Indian and Pakistan and claimed in full by both.

H.text: India-Pakistan peace process is producing tangible dividends.
H.ref: Of all the signs the India-Pakistan peace process is producing tangible dividends, one stands out: Kashmir is running low on chickens.

H.text: Economic ties between India and Pakistan improved after peace talks.
H.ref: Economic ties between India and Pakistan improved after peace talks began last year.

H.text: Kashmir is running low on chickens.
H.ref: Of all the signs the India-Pakistan peace process is producing tangible dividends, one stands out: Kashmir is running low on chickens.

H.text: Pervez Musharraff is the president of Pakistan.
H.ref: The moderate wing of Indian Kashmir's main separatist alliance said Monday it will meet Pakistan President Pervez Musharraff when he visits New Delhi this weekend, local media reported.

H.text: Pervez Musharraff will visit New Delhi.
H.ref: The moderate wing of Indian Kashmir's main separatist alliance said Monday it will meet Pakistan President Pervez Musharraff when he visits New Delhi this weekend, local media reported.

H.text: The moderate wing of Indian Kashmir's main separatist alliance will meet Pervez Musharraff.
H.ref: The moderate wing of Indian Kashmir's main separatist alliance said Monday it will meet Pakistan President Pervez Musharraff when he visits New Delhi this weekend, local media reported.

H.text: Manmohan Singh is the Indian Prime Minister.
H.ref: He will also hold talks with Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh -- their first formal talks since Singh became premier last May.

H.text: Manmohan Singh has invited Kashmir's separatists for peace talks.
H.ref: Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh has invited Kashmir's separatists for peace talks _ a move that could boost efforts to end India and Pakistan's decades-old dispute over the Himalayan region.

H.text: Indian and Pakistan leaders met in April 2005.
H.ref: Suspected Muslim rebels killed three policemen, a state political party member and two others in the first attacks on police in Kashmir since Indian and Pakistan leaders met two week's ago, police said Thursday.

H.text: Kashmir is a Muslim-majority state.
H.ref: The peace process was launched in early 2004 to resolve eight issues including the dispute over the Muslim-majority Himalayan state of Kashmir, which is divided between Indian and Pakistan and claimed in full by both.

H.text: Kashmir is divided between India and Pakistan.
H.ref: The peace process was launched in early 2004 to resolve eight issues including the dispute over the Muslim-majority Himalayan state of Kashmir, which is divided between Indian and Pakistan and claimed in full by both.

H.text: Kashmir is claimed in full by India and Pakistan.
H.ref: The peace process was launched in early 2004 to resolve eight issues including the dispute over the Muslim-majority Himalayan state of Kashmir, which is divided between Indian and Pakistan and claimed in full by both.

H.text: Suspected Muslim rebels killed three policemen.
H.ref: Suspected Muslim rebels killed three policemen, a state political party member and two others in the first attacks on police in Kashmir since Indian and Pakistan leaders met two week's ago, police said Thursday.

H.text: Suspected Muslim rebels killed a state political party member.
H.ref: Suspected Muslim rebels killed three policemen, a state political party member and two others in the first attacks on police in Kashmir since Indian and Pakistan leaders met two week's ago, police said Thursday.

H.text: There is a dispute between India and Pakistan over Kashmir.
H.ref: Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh has invited Kashmir's separatists for peace talks _ a move that could boost efforts to end India and Pakistan's decades-old dispute over the Himalayan region.

H.text: Pakistan and India were due to hold meetings.
H.ref: Pakistan and India were due to hold meetings of a long-dormant joint economic body for the first time in 16 years Tuesday, marking a further thaw between the South Asian rivals, officials said.

H.text: Pakistan and India are rivals.
H.ref: Pakistan and India were due to hold meetings of a long-dormant joint economic body for the first time in 16 years Tuesday, marking a further thaw between the South Asian rivals, officials said.

H.text: Muzaffarabad is the capital of the Pakistan-administered Kashmir.
H.ref: The first bus service spanning divided Kashmir in nearly 60 years ran simultaneously Thursday from Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian Kashmir and Muzaffarabad, capital of the Pakistan-administered zone.

H.text: Srinagar is the summer capital of Indian Kashmir.
H.ref: The first bus service spanning divided Kashmir in nearly 60 years ran simultaneously Thursday from Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian Kashmir and Muzaffarabad, capital of the Pakistan-administered zone.

H.text: Mirwaiz Umar Farooq is the leader of the All Parties Hurriyat Conference.
H.ref: "It's been a very successful trip for us," said Mirwaiz Umar Farooq, leader of the moderate faction of Kashmir's main separatist alliance, the All Parties Hurriyat Conference.

H.text: Separatist leaders in Indian Kashmir seek a three-way dialogue with the Indian and Pakistan governments.
H.ref: Separatist leaders in Indian Kashmir seek a three-way dialogue with the Indian and Pakistan governments to sort out the region's future.

H.text: Moderate separatist leaders from Indian Kashmir returned home from a historic trip to Pakistan.
H.ref: Moderate separatist leaders from Indian Kashmir returned home Thursday from a historic trip to Pakistan in upbeat mood, saying they were ready to hold a new round of talks with New Delhi on the future of the troubled Himalayan region.

H.text: Shaukat Aziz is the Prime Minister of Pakistan.
H.ref: During their visit, the Hurriyat leaders held talks with Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf, Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz, and a host of other leaders, including Syed Salahuddin, chief of a broad alliance of groups battling Indian rule in Muslim-majority Kashmir.
